docs.snippet: Should terrorists or cyclones choose to bring devastation to the Upper East Side, a band of unlikely defenders is ready and waiting.    Since April, about two dozen members of the East 79th Street Association have been learning to do things like p...
docs.abstract: Dozen members of East 79th Street Assn, most of them middle-aged and elderly women, are completing nine-week course offered by city's Office of Emergency Management to train civilians to provide help during catastrophes or natural disasters until emergency services arrive; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Should terrorists or cyclones choose to bring devastation to the Upper East Side, a band of unlikely defenders is ready and waiting. Since April, about two dozen members of the East 79th Street Association have been learning to do things like put out fires, recover bodies trapped under rubble and escape from a smoky subway.

headline.main: The Day After Tomorrow (or Soon), They'll Be Ready if Disaster Strikes

docs.abstract: departs for tour; puts Landon on footing of all Govs

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt left Washington late this evening for a tour of the drought regions, including visits to eight States and conferences with sixteen Governors.

headline.main: President Departs for Drought Area Tour; Puts Landon on Footing of All Governors

docs.snippet: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 19. -Moving to meet the growing relief need in the Western drought area, President Roosevelt approved today an increase in the number of Works Progress Administration subsistence jobs there from 90,000, the current figure, to...
docs.abstract: Member of conf on drought relief

byline.original: By CHARLES W. HURDSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 19. -Moving to meet the growing relief need in the Western drought area, President Roosevelt approved today an increase in the number of Works Progress Administration subsistence jobs there from 90,000, the current figure, to a minimum of 120,000 or a maximum of 150,000.

headline.main: INCREASE IN DROUGHT JOBS ORDERED BY ROOSEVELT; HE WILL ASK MORE FUNDS; COST $7,500,000 MONTHLY Additions to WPA Ranks Will Upset Previous Plan of Expenditures. HOPKINS ASKED INCREASE With Morgenthau and Other Officials He Goes Over Needs of Farmers. WORK DEPENDS ON WINTER If Weather Is Severe, Hyde Park Conferees Agree, Other Means Must Be Sought. ROOSEVELT WIDENS DROUGHT RELIEF

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Plans by which seven Federal agencies will start preliminary work by August on a unified and comprehensive flood control program in New York State, Pennsylvania and Ohio were agreed upon today at a meeting here of Federal o...
docs.abstract: Funds made available for preliminary work in N Y S, Pa and Ohio

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Plans by which seven Federal agencies will start preliminary work by August on a unified and comprehensive flood control program in New York State, Pennsylvania and Ohio were agreed upon today at a meeting here of Federal officials and representatives of regional flood control agencies.

headline.main: FLOOD CONTROL JOB TO START IN AUGUST; Seven Federal Agencies Map Work in Pennsylvania, New York and Ohio. SMALL PROJECTS TO OPEN Army's Task of Building Large Dams and Reservoirs Must Await Funds From Congress.

docs.snippet: BINGHAMTON, July 11 (AP). -- Seeking immediate funds for preliminary work, the executive committee of the Flood Control Council of Central-Southern New York authorized today the appointment of a committee to call on President Roosevelt at Hyde Par...
docs.abstract: Flood Control Council of Central-Southern N Y appts com to call on Roosevelt seeking immediate funds for preliminary work
docs.lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, July 11 (AP). -- Seeking immediate funds for preliminary work, the executive committee of the Flood Control Council of Central-Southern New York authorized today the appointment of a committee to call on President Roosevelt at Hyde Park Monday.

headline.main: SEEK TO PUSH FLOOD AID; Up-State Leaders, 'Sick of Delays,' Will Call on Roosevelt.

docs.abstract: Confers with Roosevelt on drought relief

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The government prepared today to put many millions of dollars into the drought-stricken area of South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana. Official reports show that an exodus of sufferers already has begun and that the drought is as serious, in a more limited area, as that in the entire plains territory in 1934.

headline.main: DROUGHT AREA AID GOES TO NORTHWEST; President Tells Tugwell to Make Survey of Needs in Montana and Dakotas. UP TO $100,000,000 ASKED Nye and Governors Welford and Berry Visit White House -- Crop Loss Increases.
